title: Beyond Meat Stock Dropped Because Serious Competition Is Closing In — Fast
text:
Text size

Beyond Meat shares are falling because of what happened to a competitor. Reuters reported Dave & Buster’s was bumping Beyond peer Impossible Foods, testing instead the new Lightlife brand made by competitor Maple Leaf Foods.

Beyond Meat shares (ticker: BYND) dropped 5.3%, to close at $117.35. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, by comparison, rose 0.1%. Maple Leaf stock (MFI.Canada) finished up 3.7%.

Recently, Beyond Meat and privately held Impossible Foods have had a string of product placement successes, including Subway, Dunkin’ Brands Group (DNKN) and Restaurant Brands International’s (QSR) Burger King.

Thursday’s news, however, could mean the alternative-meat industry is entering a new phase where bullish Beyond Meat investors have to digest wins from new competitors.

The back story. The growth of Beyond Meat has been impressive. Sales grew 287% year over year in the second quarter, and Wall Street reckons full-year sales will total more than $420 million in 2020, up about 60% from 2019.

The stock has responded to the rapid growth. Shares are up more than 375% from the $25 IPO price, making Beyond stock the best-performing IPO of 2019.

What’s new. Earlier in 2019, Beyond benefited from restaurant announcements, as predicted by J.P. Morgan analyst Ken Goldman in April, when he started covering the company.

“We would not be surprised if a large quick-service restaurant were added as a customer this year,” Goldman wrote in his launch report. “For what it is worth, board member Don Thompson, who owns approximately 5% of the Beyond shares, is the former CEO of McDonald’s. ”

Goldman’s call looks prescient. The stock jumped more than 11% after McDonald’s (MCD) announced it was testing Beyond products in some Canadian stores back in September.

Though today’s news doesn’t mention Beyond Meat, the Maple Leaf Food offering is news for investors who weren’t paying close attention to the Canadian protein company. (The company had mentioned alternative-meat plans on recent conference calls.)

Looking ahead. It’s possible investors might find themselves on the other side of Goldman’s call—when competitor announcements could hurt Beyond Meant’s stock more than new adds could help it.

There is certainly plenty of growth left in the category. Wall Street estimates the global alternative-meat category could hit anywhere from $15 to $40 billion in 10 years from less than $1 billion in new alternative-meat products now.

What’s less clear is the number of companies that will vie for the business. In addition to Maple Leaf Foods, Kellogg (K), Tyson Foods (TSN), Kraft Heinz (KHC), and Nestlé (NESN.Switzerland) have or plan to have competitive offerings soon—in addition to myriad private players trying to break into the new industry.

Beyond Meat reports third-quarter numbers on Oct. 28. Almost 50% of shares outstanding are sold short by bearish investors betting the stock price will go down. That level of short interest is multiple times the average company—and means that investors should steel themselves for a bumpy ride.
